G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as incorporated and applied to custody and parenting matters in the Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may “make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parents” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Division of the Probate and Family Court because this Court issued the existing custody and parenting order dated June 15, 2021, and because the child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 208, § 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 7 (where applicable).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 7.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Division of the Probate and Family Court because this Court issued the existing custody and parenting order dated June 15, 2021, and because the child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 208, § 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 7 (where applicable).

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time issues affecting the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (“UCCJEA”), G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time issues affecting the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (“UCCJEA”), G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31 emphasizes that custody and visitation determinations must be based on the best interests of the child, including the child’s welfare, happiness, and development, and directs the Court to consider stability, continuity, and the child’s relationship with each parent.

G.L. c. 31, \u00a7 31.proposition: Find that modification of the existing parenting-time schedule is necessary and appropriate to serve the best interests of the minor child, Emily Johnson, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 31, § 31, and applicable case law;

Champagne v. Champagne, 429 Mass. 324 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting-time order requires a showing of both a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Champagne v. Champagne*, 429 Mass. 324 (1999); *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
Champagne v. Champagne, 429 Mass. 324 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Champagne v. Champagne deals exclusively with the Probate and Family Court’s authority under G.L. c. 208, § 18 to issue and incorporate permanent protective orders into divorce judgments. It does not discuss standards or requirements for modifying custody or parenting-time orders, nor does it mention a “material and substantial change in circumstances” or “best interests of the child” in the context of modification. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Champagne v. Champagne, 429 Mass. 324 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that G. L. c. 208, § 18, authorizes the Probate and Family Court to issue permanent protective orders in divorce proceedings and to incorporate them into final judgments of divorce nisi. The second sentence of G. L. c. 208, § 18, which grants broad power to the Probate and Family Court without explicit time limits, indicates that such action is within the court’s powers and is consistent with the policy surrounding abuse prevention statutes.”

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting-time order requires a showing of both a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Champagne v. Champagne*, 429 Mass. 324 (1999); *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns child support between never-married parents with shared physical custody and high incomes; it does not address modification standards for custody or parenting-time orders. There is no discussion of the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances, nor of the best-interests test in the context of modifying an existing custody or parenting-time order. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: Therefore, insofar as it orders the father to pay child support and the mother to pay for child care and the costs of the child’s extracurricular expenses and private school attendance, the judgment must be vacated and the case remanded for further findings and a determination as to the amount of child support due to the mother from the father, if any, by application of the version of the guidelines in effect at the time of such determination.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly grounds its analysis in the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and describes that standard as the governing, paramount principle in custody determinations. The court traces the historical use of the best‑interests standard in Massachusetts custody law and reaffirms that custody decisions must be based on what is best for the child, confirming that this is the controlling consideration in such cases.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effects in custody determinations, but it does not clearly articulate a general rule that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in all custody or parenting-time decisions. While the court implicitly evaluates factors related to the child’s welfare, it does not set out or emphasize the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the governing, paramount consideration, nor does it cite G.L. c. 208, § 28. Thus it only indirectly reflects that framework rather than expressly supporting the stated proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: In determining best interests, the Court considers, among other things: the child’s age and developmental needs; the child’s relationship with each parent; the child’s educational and emotional needs; the stability of each parent’s home; and the effect of travel and transitions on the child. See *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The Hugo opinion certainly applies a broad ‘best interests’ analysis and discusses factors like the child’s developmental needs, attachments, stability of home, and the effect of transitions. However, it does not articulate the specific, enumerated list in the proposition (age and developmental needs; relationship with each parent; educational and emotional needs; stability of each parent’s home; effect of travel and transitions) as a formal test or framework. The case is about choosing between two non-parent caretakers, not weighing each parent’s home, and the court does not set out that multi-factor list as a governing standard, so the citation overstates what Hugo itself holds.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision’… Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: In determining best interests, the Court considers, among other things: the child’s age and developmental needs; the child’s relationship with each parent; the child’s educational and emotional needs; the stability of each parent’s home; and the effect of travel and transitions on the child. See *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames the removal inquiry as a best-interests analysis and identifies specific factors it deems relevant, including the child’s developmental and educational needs, his existing school supports, the disruption of moving homes and schools, the impact on the father’s parenting time, and the burdens of travel and distance between households. While Mason is a relocation case rather than a general custody case, its best-interests discussion expressly includes stability of each household and the effects of travel and transitions, consistent with the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’ … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Maintaining frequent and meaningful contact with both parents is important, but it must be structured in a way that does not unduly disrupt the child’s schooling, sleep, health, or emotional well-being. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (2005).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on relocation and the ‘real advantage’ standard, considering the impact of a move on the child’s relationship with the noncustodial parent. It does not discuss structuring visitation to avoid disrupting schooling, sleep, health, or emotional well-being, nor does it articulate a principle about “frequent and meaningful contact” needing to be balanced against such disruptions. The case is about whether relocation is in the child’s best interests overall, not about how to structure ongoing contact schedules to avoid undue disruption.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (2005)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.proposition: Maintaining frequent and meaningful contact with both parents is important, but it must be structured in a way that does not unduly disrupt the child’s schooling, sleep, health, or emotional well-being. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (2005).
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.case_name: Massachusetts Correction Officers Federated Union v. Commissioner of Correction
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.support_reasoning: This opinion is about enforcement and confirmation of a labor arbitration award under G.L. c. 150C, § 10, not about child custody, parenting time, or the impact of visitation on a child’s schooling, sleep, health, or emotional well-being. It contains no discussion of best interests of the child or maintaining contact with both parents. The citation to Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser for that family-law proposition is therefore misplaced in light of this text, which concerns union and correction department disputes.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: "A dispute arose between the Massachusetts Correction Officers Federated Union (union) and the Department of Correction (department) as to whether a union member (Salmon) had been properly demoted for just cause... The union filed a grievance... and the case was eventually heard by an arbitrator. The arbitrator directed the department to 'rescind the demotion and to substitute in its place a twenty workday unpaid suspension'..."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20134.proposition: Stable school-week routines and predictable attendance are central to Emily’s academic performance and emotional regulation. See, as guidance, *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 842–43 (stability and continuity are key best-interests factors).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant changes in a parent’s residence and the resulting impact on a child’s schedule, school life, and emotional health can justify modification of parenting-time arrangements. See, e.g., *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Murphy v. Murphy*, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513 (1986); *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (.support_reasoning: The proposition is about modification of parenting-time (or custody/visitation) arrangements based on significant changes in a parent’s residence and impact on a child’s schedule, school, and emotional health. Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, deciding whether the mother may remove the children from Massachusetts when there is joint physical custody. The Court applies a best‑interests removal standard, not a post‑judgment modification standard, and does not hold that a residential change justifies modifying parenting time; rather, it denies the requested relocation and leaves the existing shared physical custody arrangement in place. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the mother wishes to remove the children from the Commonwealth, and the father, who shares legal and physical custody with her, has refused to consent. The mother has thus requested permission from the court to remove the children. General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Murphy v. Murphy, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513.raw_text: Murphy v. Murphy, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513 (1986)
Murphy v. Murphy, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant changes in a parent’s residence and the resulting impact on a child’s schedule, school life, and emotional health can justify modification of parenting-time arrangements. See, e.g., *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Murphy v. Murphy*, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513 (1986); *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
Murphy v. Murphy, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513.support_reasoning: This opinion is a medical malpractice case about causation and jury instructions, not a family-law or custody/parenting-time case. It does not discuss parental relocation, changes in a parent’s residence, or any impact on a child’s schedule, schooling, or emotional health, nor does it address modification of parenting-time arrangements. Citing this decision for the stated custody/parenting-time proposition is therefore inaccurate.
Murphy v. Murphy, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513.relevant_excerpt: “We reverse the judgment because of the trial judge’s failure to instruct the jury, over the timely request and specific objection of the plaintiff’s counsel, that, if found negligent, the defendant could also be found responsible for any additional injury caused by the doctor who performed the surgery.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions have consistently held that modification of custody or parenting-time orders is appropriate when: (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) the proposed modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests. See *Champagne v. Champagne*, 429 Mass. 324 (1999); *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226 (2012); *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation/removal, not on the general standard for modification of existing custody or parenting-time orders. It does not articulate or apply the two-prong “material and substantial change in circumstances” plus “best interests” test that governs modification proceedings. Thus, as presented, Smith v. McDonald does not provide direct authority for the broad modification standard stated in the proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003)... The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts.

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: When geography, travel demands, or changed family circumstances undermine the practical functioning of an existing schedule or adversely affect a child’s schooling and emotional well-being, courts have authority to adjust parenting time accordingly. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Murphy v. Murphy*, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 513 (1986); *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The Williams v. Massa opinion deals with property division, alimony, child support, attorney’s fees, and the procedural mechanism for modifying custody (requiring a complaint for modification rather than a motion). It does not discuss geography, travel burdens, schooling logistics, or similar practical schedule problems as a basis for adjusting parenting time. Its custody discussion focuses on parental fitness and decision-making for special‑needs children, not on travel or changed geographic circumstances undermining an existing schedule, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Mother’s proposed modification is narrowly tailored to the specific changes arising from Father’s relocation and is consistent with Massachusetts law favoring arrangements that foster the child’s welfare and stability. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590; *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde concerns initial divorce, custody, property division, and visitation, not a post‑judgment modification arising from a parent’s relocation. While it does reaffirm the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard and the importance of stability and minimizing disruption, it does not discuss G.L. c. 208, § 28 or standards for tailoring a modification to changes like a move. Thus it provides only general best‑interests language, not authority for the specific proposition about a relocation‑based modification being narrowly tailored.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”
